**Objective:** In this exercise, you will practice working with HDFS—the Hadoop Distributed File System—using the HDFS command line interface.
**File locations:** s3://shared-edu/dev/
**Successful outcome:**
**Before you begin:**

paragraphs.title: Required for Kerberos operations
Setup the data context
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -rm -r -f loudacre
aws s3 cp --recursive s3://shared-edu/dev/activations data/activations
rm -rf downloads
mkdir -p downloads/activations

%md
## Explore HDFS Using the Command Line Interface

msg.data: Explore HDFS Using the Command Line Interface

paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the HDFS command line to list the content of the HDFS root directory using the following command:

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -ls /
```

msg.data:
Use the HDFS command line to list the content of the HDFS root directory using the following command:

$ hdfs dfs -ls /

paragraphs.title: 1 - List the content of the HDFS root directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
View the content of the /user directory.

You will see your home directory in the listing.

> #### Relative Paths
In HDFS, relative (non-absolute) paths are considered relative to your home directory. 
There is no concept of a “current” or “working” directory as there is in Linux and similar filesystems.

msg.data:
View the content of the /user directory.

You will see your home directory in the listing.

Relative Paths

In HDFS, relative (non-absolute) paths are considered relative to your home directory.
There is no concept of a “current” or “working” directory as there is in Linux and similar filesystems.

paragraphs.title: 2 - View the content of the /user directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
List the contents of your home directory by running:

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -ls
```
Note that the directory structure in HDFS is unrelated to the directory structure of the local filesystem on the remote host; they are completely separate namespaces.

msg.data:
List the contents of your home directory by running:

$ hdfs dfs -ls

Note that the directory structure in HDFS is unrelated to the directory structure of the local filesystem on the remote host; they are completely separate namespaces.

paragraphs.title: 3 - List the content of your home directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new directory called loudacre in your home directory. 
The new directory will be the top-level directory for the remaining exercises in the course.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -mkdir loudacre
```

msg.data:
Create a new directory called loudacre in your home directory.
The new directory will be the top-level directory for the remaining exercises in the course.

$ hdfs dfs -mkdir loudacre

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create the loudacre directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
Insert the activations directory into HDFS:

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -put data/activations loudacre/
```

This copies the local 'activations' directory and its contents into a remote HDFS directory named 'activations'.

msg.data:
Insert the activations directory into HDFS:

$ hdfs dfs -put data/activations loudacre/

This copies the local 'activations' directory and its contents into a remote HDFS directory named 'activations'.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Insert the activations directory into HDFS
6 - Confirm the upload by listing the contents of the new directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
View some of the data you just copied into HDFS.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -cat loudacre/activations/2014-03.xml | head -n 20
```

This prints the first 20 lines of the article to your terminal. This command is handy for viewing text data in HDFS. An individual file is often very large, making it inconvenient to view the entire file in the terminal. For this reason, it is often a good idea to pipe the output of the dfs -cat command into head, more, or less. You can also use hdfs dfs -tail to more efficiently view the end of the file, rather than piping the whole content.
Note: You may see a warning: cat: Unable to write to output stream. This is because the cat was only able to pipe the first 20 lines because of the limit specified in the head command. You can disregard the warning.

msg.data:
View some of the data you just copied into HDFS.

$ hdfs dfs -cat loudacre/activations/2014-03.xml | head -n 20

This prints the first 20 lines of the article to your terminal. This command is handy for viewing text data in HDFS. An individual file is often very large, making it inconvenient to view the entire file in the terminal. For this reason, it is often a good idea to pipe the output of the dfs -cat command into head, more, or less. You can also use hdfs dfs -tail to more efficiently view the end of the file, rather than piping the whole content.
Note: You may see a warning: cat: Unable to write to output stream. This is because the cat was only able to pipe the first 20 lines because of the limit specified in the head command. You can disregard the warning.

paragraphs.title: 7 - View some of the data you just copied into HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%md
Practice downloading from HDFS by downloading the directory you uploaded above.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -get loudacre/activations/ /tmp/activations
```

msg.data:
Practice downloading from HDFS by downloading the directory you uploaded above.

$ hdfs dfs -get loudacre/activations/ /tmp/activations

paragraphs.title: 8 - Practice downloading from HDFS by downloading the directory you uploaded above
9 - List the content of the directory in which you downloaded

paragraphs.text:
%md
Remove the directory you uploaded earlier.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -rm -r loudacre/activations/
```

msg.data:
Remove the directory you uploaded earlier.

$ hdfs dfs -rm -r loudacre/activations/

paragraphs.title: 10 - Remove the directory you uploaded earlier

paragraphs.text:
%md
There are several other operations available with the hdfs dfs command to perform most common filesystem manipulations such as mv, cp, and mkdir.
Using the hdfs dfs command with no arguments will display the available commands.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs
```

msg.data:
There are several other operations available with the hdfs dfs command to perform most common filesystem manipulations such as mv, cp, and mkdir.
Using the hdfs dfs command with no arguments will display the available commands.

$ hdfs dfs

paragraphs.title: 11 - Optional: Continue exploring the HDFS filesystem by experimenting with some of these commands

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Result
**You have now:** practiced working with HDFS using the command line interface.

---

Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Cloudera Tutorials](http://cloudera.com/tutorials.html) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Cloudera Community](https://community.cloudera.com) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Apache Spark Documentation](https://spark.apache.org/documentation.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Apache Zeppelin Project Home Page](https://zeppelin.apache.org) - official Zeppelin web site.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Cloudera Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Cloudera Community is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
  3. Apache Spark Documentation - official Spark documentation.
  4. Apache Zeppelin Project Home Page - official Zeppelin web site.

<script type="text/javascript">
function runMarkdown() {
  
  let zeppelinApiUrl = "https://knguyen-spark-3-master0.knguyen.kfjr-x0dh.cloudera.site/knguyen-spark-3/cdp-proxy/zeppelin/api/";
  let baseUrl = "https://bshimel.github.io/ztest/notebooks/";

  function getNotebookInfo(notebookId) {
    $.ajax({
      url : zeppelinApiUrl + "notebook/" + notebookId,
      type : 'GET',
      dataType:'json',
      xhrFields: {
        withCredentials: true
      },
      success : function(data) {
        data.body.paragraphs.forEach(paragraph => {
          if (paragraph['text'].startsWith("%md") && !paragraph['results']) {
            runParagraph(notebookId, paragraph['id']);
          }
        });
      },
      error : function(request,error)
      {
          console.log("Request: "+JSON.stringify(request));
      }
    });
  }

  function runParagraph(notebookId, paragraphId) {
    $.ajax({
      url : zeppelinApiUrl + "notebook/job/" + notebookId + "/" + paragraphId,
      type : 'POST',
      dataType:'json',
      xhrFields: {
        withCredentials: true
      },
      success : function(data) {
        console.log("Ran " + notebookId + ", " + paragraphId);
      },
      error : function(request,error)
      {
          console.log("Request: "+JSON.stringify(request));
      }
    });
  }

  let pathArray = window.location.href.split('/');
  let notebookId = pathArray.pop();
  getNotebookInfo(notebookId);
}

runMarkdown();
</script>
